title: Ticket #7752: RPM installs fail without adding EPEL repo
description:
At least on Centos7, any attempt to install HTCondor RPMs fails because the of an undeclared dependency on packages from the EPEL repository. The breaking change appears to have happened back in v8.8.4 with ticket #6327 [57288]. I am not enough of a packaging expert to say if this should be fixed via documentation, or if it is acceptable to simply have the HTCondor RPMs add the EPEL repo as a dependency (hoping adding EPEL as a dependency is acceptable practice). But currently following our documentation that says how to install HTCondor RPMs results in failure.

For example, here are the errors reported when trying to do a yum install minicondor on a Centos7 image: 

   --> Finished Dependency Resolution
Error: Package: python2-condor-8.8.9-1.el7.x86_64 (htcondor-stable)
           Requires: boost169-python2
Error: Package: python3-condor-8.8.9-1.el7.x86_64 (htcondor-stable)
           Requires: libboost_python36.so.1.69.0()(64bit)
Error: Package: python3-condor-8.8.9-1.el7.x86_64 (htcondor-stable)
           Requires: boost169-python3
Error: Package: python2-condor-8.8.9-1.el7.x86_64 (htcondor-stable)
           Requires: libboost_python27.so.1.69.0()(64bit)
remarks:
2020-Jul-24 12:26:45 by matyas:
Software packages adding repos is unfortunately not acceptable practice, so this will have to be fixed in documentation.

Note that in CentOS 8, in addition to EPEL, users have to enable the PowerTools repo by editing /etc/yum.repos.d/CentOS-PowerTools.repo and setting enabled=1

2020-Jul-24 13:46:21 by tannenba:
Ugh, so painful. I think we are at the point where we need our installation directions to be something like 

   curl -s https://htcondor.org/install_htcondor | bash

and then the script can look at the system and figure out which RPM or apt commands are required....
